metadata.title: Slow entropy of some combinatorial constructions

abstract.text: Measure-theoretic slow entropy is a more refined invariant than the classical measure-theoretic entropy to characterize the complexity of dynamical systems with subexponential growth rates of distinguishable orbit types. In this paper we prove flexibility results for the values of upper and lower polynomial slow entropy of rigid transformations as well as maps admitting a good cyclic approximation. Moreover, we show that there cannot exist a general upper bound on the lower measuretheoretic slow entropy for systems of finite rank. of distinguishable orbit types and it does not provide any information for systems with

body_text.text: Dating back to the foundational paper of J. von Neumann [N32] the classification of measure-preserving transformations (MPT's) up to isomorphism is a fundamental theme in ergodic theory. While the isomorphism problem for general ergodic transformations remains intractable and is inaccessible to countable methods that use countable amount of information [FRW11] , it has been solved for some special classes of transformations. Two great successes are the Halmos-von Neumann classification of ergodic MPT's with pure point spectrum by countable subgroups of the unit circle [HN42] and D. Ornstein's classification of Bernoulli shifts by their measure-theoretic entropy [O70] .

In general, measure-theoretic entropy plays a central role in structural questions for dynamical systems and is a crucial tool in detecting chaoticity of a system. However, the measure-theoretic entropy is positive if and only if the system has exponential growth slower orbit growth. To measure the complexity of systems with subexponential orbit growth several invariants like sequence entropy by A. Kushnirenko [K67] , slow entropy by A. Katok and J.-P. Thouvenot [KT97] , measure-theoretic complexity by S. Ferenczi [Fer97M] , entropy dimension by M. de Carvalho [C97] , entropy convergence rate by F. Blume ([Blu97] , [Blu12] , [Blu15] ), scaled entropy by A.Vershik [Ver00] , and amorphic complexity by G. Fuhrmann, M. Gröger, and T. Jäger have been introduced and studied intensely (e.g. [Go74] , [K77] , [H82] , [HSY05] , [FP07] , [VG07] , [ADP10] , [DHP11] , [Ver11] , [HKM14] , [CKpp] , [H12] , [KVW19] , [KKVWpp] , [Veppp] ). We refer to the recent survey article [KKWpp] for definitions and further background. In this paper we focus on measure-theoretic slow entropy (see Section 2.1) and address three problems stated in [KKWpp] .

Motivated by results of Ferenczi [Fer97M,  Proposition 5] and Kanigowski [Kan18, Proposition 1.3] showing that the lower measure-theoretic slow entropy of rank-one systems with respect to the polynomial scaling function a n (t) = n t is bounded from above by 1, Question 6.2.1 in [KKWpp] asks about the slow entropy for systems of finite rank. On the one hand, we prove in Proposition 6.1 that every rank-two transformation without spacers has lower measure-theoretic polynomial slow entropy at most 1. In fact, the proof of Proposition 6.1 also gives that any finite rank system with bounded height ratio has linear complexity, see Remark 6.2 for more details. On the other hand, we show in Section 6.2 that there cannot be a general bound on the lower measure-theoretic slow entropy for systems of finite rank.

Theorem 1.1 (Slow entropy of finite rank system). For any scaling function {a n (t)} n∈N,t>0 satisfying lim n→+∞ log an(t) n = 0, there exists an ergodic measure-preserving rank two system (T, X, B, µ X ) such that its lower slow entropy ent µ X an(t) (T ) = +∞, where X is a finite interval of [0, +∞), µ X (A) = µ(A∩X) µ(X) for any A ∈ B and µ is the Lebesgue measure of R.

The construction bases upon the cutting-and-stacking technique (cf. [F70] ) and uses additional spacer levels. The idea of the construction is to construct a rank-two system such that the height ratio between the two towers goes to infinity by adding spacers in a staircase-like manner to the shorter tower at each step and exchanging mass between the short tower and tall tower using a probabilistic approach. Roughly speaking, the "staircase-like" spacers forbids the long matching phenomenon in the short tower part and "randomness" of exchanging mass forbids the long matching phenomenon in the tall tower part.

The aforementioned probabilistic approach is a key method for our constructions throughout the paper. We present it in detail in Section 3 and expect it to have further applications in combinatorial constructions.

In particular, we use it to answer Question 6.1.2 from [KKWpp] . Here, we recall that a measure preserving dynamical system (X, B, µ, T ), T is rigid if there exists an increasing sequence {t n } n∈N such that for any f ∈ L 2 (X, B, µ), T tn f → f in L 2 . Since rigid transformations always have measure-theoretic entropy zero [FW78] , Question 6.1.2 from [KKWpp] asks whether it is possible for the upper measure-theoretic slow entropy of a rigid transformation to be positive with respect to the polynomial scale a n (t) = n t . In Section 4 we answer this question in the affirmative and obtain the following flexibility result.

Theorem 1.2. For every u ∈ [0, ∞] there exists an ergodic Lebesgue measure preserving rigid transformation T with ent µ n t (T ) = u. We are even able to construct rigid transformations with positive lower measuretheoretic polynomial slow entropy. Theorem 1.3. For every u ∈ [0, ∞] there exists an ergodic Lebesgue measure preserving rigid transformation T with ent µ n t (T ) = u. Currently we do not know if there exists a rigid transformation T with ent µ n t (T ) = ent µ n t (T ) = u for some 0 < u < ∞. In Theorem 4.10 we actually show that for any given subexponential rate a n (t) there exists an ergodic Lebesgue measure preserving rigid transformation T with ent µ an(t) (T ) = ∞. Independently and by different methods, T. Adams also gave a positive answer to [KKWpp, Question 6.1.2] in his recent paper [A21] . He shows that for any given subexponential rate a n (t) there exists a rigid and weakly mixing transformation such that the lower slow entropy is infinite with respect to a n (t). While his construction uses the technique of independent cutting-and-stacking, we use an abstract Approximation by Conjugation method (also known as AbC or Anosov-Katok method).

The AbC method was developed by D. Anosov and A. Katok in [AK70] and is one of the most powerful tools of constructing smooth volume-preserving diffeomorphisms of entropy zero with prescribed ergodic or topological properties. In particular, it provided the first example of an ergodic C ∞ diffeomorphism on the disc D 2 . In a more general framework as described in [K03, chapter 8] , one can consider any measure space admitting a non-trivial circle action R = {R t } t∈S 1 . The transformations are constructed as limits of conjugates T n = H n • R α n+1 • H −1 n with α n+1 = p n+1 q n+1 = α n + 1 kn·ln·q 2 n ∈ Q and H n = H n−1 • h n , where the h n 's are measure-preserving maps in the regularity under consideration (e.g. measurable, smooth or real-analytic) satisfying R 1 qn • h n = h n • R 1 qn . In each step the conjugation map h n and the parameter k n are chosen such that the transformation T n imitates the desired property with a certain precision. In a final step of the construction, the parameter l n is chosen large enough to guarantee closeness of T n to T n−1 , and so the convergence of the sequence (T n ) n∈N to a limit transformation in the measurable, smooth, or even real-analytic category is provided. We refer to the survey articles [FK04] and [Kpp] for more information on the AbC method and its wide range of applications.

In many ways, the AbC method can be seen as a constructive and smooth version of the concept of periodic approximation in ergodic theory which was developed by A. Katok and A. Stepin [KS67] . The concept has numerous applications in measurable dynamics and helped to solve several long-standing problems dating back to von Neumann and Kolmogorov. We give a primer on periodic approximation in Section 2.3 and recommend [K03] as a comprehensive exposition of the concept.

In particular, our transformations from Theorems 1.2 and 1.3 admit periodic approximations. Hereby, these results already give a first answer to Question 6.3.1 in [KKWpp] which asks about the slow entropy of systems constructed by fast periodic approximation. A particularly important class are cyclic approximations, where the periodic process consists of a single tower (see Definition 2.11 for the precise notion). The existence of a good cyclic approximation implies various properties for the limit transformation T as summarized in [K03, Proposition 3 .2], e.g. T is ergodic, rigid, has simple spectrum and its maximal spectral type is singular. In Section 5 we continue our investigation of slow entropy for transformations with periodic approximation by realizing systems with good cyclic approximation and any given value of upper polynomial slow entropy.

Theorem 1.4. For every u ∈ [0, ∞] there exists a Lebesgue measure preserving transformation T with good cyclic approximation and ent µ n t (T ) = u. By [KS67] (see also [K03, Proposition 3 .2]) a transformation admitting a good cyclic approximation is ergodic and rigid. Hence, our construction for Theorem 1.4 provides another family of examples for Theorem 1.2. In fact, we show in Theorem 5.9 that for any subexponential scale a n (t) there is a transformation T with good cyclic approximation and ent µ an(t) = ∞. Like [A21, Theorem 1] these constructions confirm a conjecture by Ferenczi in [Fer97M, page 205 ] that there are rank one systems T with ent µ n t (T ) = ∞ (therein the conjecture is phrased in terms of the measure-theoretic complexity). To the best of our knowledge, they also provide the first standard systems (i.e. loosely Bernoulli with zero entropy or loosely Kronecker) with growth rate faster than any polynomial scale.

Since transformations with good cyclic approximations are rank one, their lower measure-theoretic polynomial slow entropy can be at most 1 by the results of Ferenczi and Kanigowski (see Proposition 5.1 for more details). We realize all possible values of the lower polynomial slow entropy.

Theorem 1.5. For every u ∈ [0, 1] there exists a Lebesgue measure preserving transformation T with good cyclic approximation and ent µ n t (T ) = u. These transformations are constructed by a twisted version of the abstract AbC method. We stress that the AbC transformations constructed in this paper are not necessarily smooth. (To guarantee smoothness further growth conditions have to be posed on the parameter sequence (l n ) n∈N .) In an accompanying paper [BKWpp] we present a method how to compute the measure-theoretic and topological slow entropy of smooth AbC diffeomorphisms.

Plan of the rest of the paper: In Section 2, we provide definitions of measuretheoretic slow entropy, finite rank systems, and periodic approximations. In Section 3, we prove a probabilistic lemma that will serve as a key tool for our combinatorial constructions throughout the paper. For instance, we will use it to determine the combinatorial mapping behavior of the conjugation maps in our AbC constructions in Sections 4 as well as 5. In Section 4, we prove the flexibility of both upper and lower measuretheoretic slow entropy of the rigid transformations with respect to polynomial scale. In Section 5, we first show the flexibility of upper measure-theoretic slow entropy for good cyclic transformations with values from 0 to +∞ with respect to polynomial scale. Then we prove flexibility of lower measure-theoretic polynomial slow entropy of good cyclic transformations with values from 0 to 1, which implies that Proposition 1.3 in [Kan18] is sharp. In Section 6, we turn to rank-two systems. We first provide an upper bound of lower measure-theoretic slow entropy for rank-two system without spacers. Then for any subexponential scale, we construct a rank-two system such that its lower measuretheoretic slow entropy is infinite with respect to the given scale.

In this setting, slow entropy of invertible measure-preserving transformations can be introduced as follows:

Definition 2.1 (Slow entropy, Katok-Thouvenot [KT97] ). Let {a n (t)} n∈N,t>0 be a family of positive sequences increasing to infinity and monotone in t. Then define the lower measure-theoretic slow entropy of T with respect to a finite measurable partition P by
The lower measure-theoretic slow entropy of T is defined by ent µ an(t) (T ) = sup P ent µ an(t) (T, P).

The upper measure-theoretic slow entropy of T can be defined in a similar way by replacing lim inf by lim sup in (2.4) and denoted as ent µ an(t) (T ). If ent µ an(t) (T ) = ent µ an(t) (T ), then we define this value as the measure-theoretic slow entropy of T with respect to a n (t) and denote it as ent µ an(t) (T ). One of the most important features of measure-theoretic slow entropy is the following generating sequence property:

Proposition 2.2 (Proposition 1 in [KT97] ). Let (X, B, µ, T ) be a measure-preserving transformation and P 1 P 2 . . . be an increasing sequence of finite measurable partitions of X such that ∨ +∞ m=1 P m generates the σ−algebra B. 2.2 Finite rank systems 8

Although there are many equivalent definitions of finite rank systems, we only provide the following geometrical definition of finite rank systems in our paper. For other equivalent definitions we refer to [Fer97S] for more details.

Definition 2.4 (Finite rank system [Fer97S] ). A system is of rank at most ℓ if for every partition P of X, for every ε > 0, there exist ℓ subsets B i of X, ℓ positive integers h i and a partition P ′ of X such that
c) P ′ is refined by the partition

A system is of rank ℓ if it is of rank at most ℓ and not of rank at most ℓ − 1. A system is of infinite rank if no such finite ℓ exists. Moreover, if X \ ∪ 1 i ℓ,0 j h i −1 T j B i = ∅, then we call such systems a finite rank systems without spacers.

Remark 2.5. It is worth to point out that for a rank ℓ-system (X, T, B, µ), each h i will go to +∞ as P converges to an atom partition and ε → 0. If there is at least one bounded h i in this process, then P → atom partition and ε → 0 imply that µ(B i ) → 0 and thus µ( h i j=0 T j B i ) → 0, which gives that the rank of T is less than or equal to ℓ − 1 and thus a contradiction.

In this section, we provide an elementary introduction about periodic approximation, which will be used in Section 5. We refer to [K03] for more details. Suppose (X, µ) is a Lebesgue space. A tower t is an ordered sequence of disjoint

where c 1 is denoted as the base of the tower t and h(t) is denoted as the height of the tower t. Moreover, we associated a cyclic measure-preserving permutation σ with tower t such that σ(c i ) = c i+1 for 1 i h(t), where c h(t)+1 = c 1 . Then the periodic process can be defined as follows:
Definition 2.7 (Periodic process). A periodic process is a collection of disjoint towers covering X, together with an equivalence relation among these towers which identifies their bases.

For any given periodic process, we introduce the following two standard partitions associated with the periodic process. The first partition ξ consists of all elements of all towers of the periodic process and the second partition η consists of the unions of bases of towers in each equivalence class and their images under the iterates of σ, where we will drop certain towers if we go beyond the heights of these towers and we continue until the highest tower in the equivalence class has been exhausted. It is clear that η is a subpartition of ξ, i.e. η ξ. In fact, (ξ, η, σ) completely determines the periodic process except for the situation that all towers within an equivalence class have the same height. Since we will not be interested in making this distinction, we identify the triple (ξ, η, σ) with the periodic process from now on. With the help of these notations, we can introduce the concept of periodic approximations:
Definition 2.8 (Exhaustive periodic process). The sequence (ξ n , η n , σ n ) of periodic processes is called exhaustive if η n converges to the decomposition into points as n → ∞.

Definition 2.9 (Periodic approximation). For a given measure-preserving transformation T and an exhaustive sequence of periodic processes (ξ n , η n , σ n ), we say (ξ n , η n , σ n ) forms a periodic approximation of T if c∈ξn µ(T c△σ n c) → 0 as n → ∞.
One of the important features of periodic approximations is the speed of approximation:

Definition 2.10. A measure-preserving transformation admits a periodic approximation (ξ n , η n , σ n ) with speed g(n) if for a certain subsequence {n k } we have c∈ξn k µ(T c△σ n k c) < g(n k ). Now we have enough ingredients to define a good cyclic approximation.

Definition 2.11 (Cyclic approximation). A periodic process which consists of a single tower is called a cyclic process. An approximation by an exhaustive sequence of cyclic processes is a cyclic approximation. In particular, a cyclic approximation is a good cyclic approximation if its speed is o( 1 qn ), where q n is the height of cyclic processes' single tower at step n.

One of the key tools for all our combinatorial constructions throughout this paper is a probabilistic method similar to the so-called "Substitution Lemma" in [FRW11] . Like [FRW11, Proposition 45] our method allows to select good choices of words so that each constructed sequence contains each letter in the underlying alphabet the same number of times and that all pairs of letters occur with about the same frequency when comparing two substantial substrings with each other, even after some sliding along the sequence. In addition to that, our word construction also takes care of Hamming-separation for substrings of shorter lengths. We need this extension in order to prove our statements on the lower slow entropy.
To state our probabilistic method precisely, we introduce some notation.

Definition 3.1. Let Σ be an alphabet. For a word w ∈ Σ k and x ∈ Σ we write r(x, w) for the number of times that x occurs in w and freq(x, w) = r(x,w) k for the frequency of occurrences of x in w. Similarly, for (w, w ′ ) ∈ Σ k × Σ k and (x, y) ∈ Σ × Σ we write r(x, y, w, w ′ ) for the number of i < k such that x is the i-th member of w and y is the i-th member of w ′ . We also introduce freq(x, y, w, w ′ ) = r(x,y,w,w ′ ) k .
We also state the Law of Large Numbers with its large deviations using Chernoff bounds:

Lemma 3.2 (Law of Large Numbers). Let (X i ) i∈N be a sequence of independent identically distributed random variables taking value 1 with probability p and taking value 0 with probability 1 − p. Then for any δ > 0 we have
and for the upper tail we have the following estimate

Inspired by the proof of the Substitution Lemma in [FRW11] we apply the Law of Large Numbers to guarantee the existence of selections of words that are Hammingapart from each other. To avoid Hamming-closeness of too many substrings of shorter length, we have to provide several extensions to [FRW11, Proposition 44] . Here, for a word w ∈ Σ k , we let sh t (w) be the word whose entries are moved to the left by t units. Furthermore, w ↾ I denotes the restriction of w on the index set I, i.e. if I = {i 1 , i 2 , . . .}, then (w ↾ I) p = w ip . With the help of these notations, our probabilistic method can be stated as follows.

The previous section already provides examples of measure preserving transformations admitting a periodic approximation with positive or even infinite lower measure-theoretic polynomial entropy. In this section we examine one particular class of periodic approximations, the so-called good cyclic approximations. We recall their definition from Definition 2.11.
body_text.section: Slow entropy for good cyclic approximations

body_text.text: On the one hand, we know that the lower measure-theoretic polynomial entropy for a transformation with good cyclic approximation is at most one following from estimates in Proposition 5 in [Fer97M] and Proposition 1.3 in [Kan18] :
body_text.section: Slow entropy for good cyclic approximations

body_text.text: Proposition 5.1. If T : (X, µ) → (X, µ) admits a good cyclic approximation, then the lower measure-theoretic slow entropy with respect to the polynomial scale a n (t) = n t is at most 1.
body_text.section: Slow entropy for good cyclic approximations

body_text.text: In fact, we show that the above estimate is optimal by Theorem 1.5: every possible value in [0, 1] is attained by a transformation admitting a good cyclic approximation.
body_text.section: Slow entropy for good cyclic approximations

body_text.text: On the other hand, we are able to construct transformations admitting a good cyclic approximation with positive or even infinite upper measure-theoretic polynomial entropy in Theorem 1.4, which exhibits different features of upper and lower measure-theoretic slow entropy.

In this section, we discuss the slow entropy of finite rank systems. We first provide an upper bound for the lower slow entropy of rank-two systems without any spacers. Then for any given subexponential scale we construct a rank-two system such that its lower slow entropy is infinity with respect to the given scale.

body_text.text: The construction of our desired finite rank system is a rank-two system with spacers. More precisely, we proceed the construction by cutting-and-stacking method with two towers and several spacer levels, where the ratio of heights of the two towers is increasing to infinity and grows faster than a given subexponential scaling function {a n (t)} n∈N,t>0 (see (6.2) and (6.5)). Then the inductive processes (especially step (vi)) guarantee that the growth rate of the number of Hamming balls we need to cover a significant part of the higher tower is faster than the speed given by {a n (t)} n∈N,t>0 (see Proposition 6.7).

Outline of the proof: The estimate of lower slow entropy can be divided into three parts. The first part is Lemma 6.5, which estimates under some assumptions of codings for the shorter tower the Hamming distance between "basic blocks" that are constructed in step (iv). The second part is Lemma 6.6, which shows by induction that the assumptions in Lemma 6.5 always hold true. The third part is Proposition 6.7, which gives a lower bound for the cardinality of minimal covers along certain subsequences by using Lemma 6.6 and combinatorial estimates.

We first show that T preserves Lebesgue measure µ. By the construction of T , we know that there exist countable disjoint intervals I i ⊂ X for i ∈ I such that ∪ I I i = X and T is measure preserving from I i to T (I i ). Let A ⊂ X be a measurable subset, then there exists a countable decomposition of A into A i = A ∩ I i for i ∈ I such that A = ∪ i∈I A i . Since T is a measure preserving map on each interval I i , we have µ(A i ) = µ(T −1 (A i )) = µ(T (A i )), which gives that µ(A) = µ(T −1 (A)) = µ(T (A)).
